member.name: M:NumpyDotNet.np.reshape(NumpyDotNet.ndarray,NumpyDotNet.shape,NumpyLib.NPY_ORDER)
member.summary: Gives a new shape to an array without changing its data.
member.param: Array to be reshaped

The new shape should be compatible with the original shape. If an integer, then the result will be a 1-D array of that length. One shape dimension can be -1. In this case, the value is inferred from the length of the array and remaining dimensions.

(Optional) {‘C’, ‘F’, ‘A’} ,Read the elements of a using this index order, and place the elements into the reshaped array using this index order. ‘C’ means to read / write the elements using C-like index order
member.returns: This will be a new view object if possible; otherwise, it will be a copy.Note there is no guarantee of the memory layout (C- or Fortran- contiguous) of the returned array.

member.name: M:NumpyDotNet.np.arange(System.Int64,System.Nullable{System.Int64},System.Nullable{System.Int64},NumpyDotNet.dtype)
member.summary: Return evenly spaced values within a given interval.
member.param: Start of interval. The interval includes this value. The default start value is 0.
End of interval. The interval does not include this value, except in some cases where step is not an integer and floating point round-off affects the length of out.
Spacing between values. For any output out, this is the distance between two adjacent values, out[i+1] - out[i]. The default step size is 1. If step is specified, start must also be given.
The type of the output array. If dtype is not given, infer the data type from the other input arguments.
member.returns: Array of evenly spaced values
member.notes: For floating point arguments, the length of the result is ceil((stop - start)/step). Because of floating point overflow, this rule may result in the last element of out being greater than stop.
When using a non-integer step, such as 0.1, the results will often not be consistent. It is better to use linspace for these cases.

member.name: M:NumpyDotNet.np.arange(System.Double,System.Nullable{System.Double},System.Nullable{System.Double},NumpyDotNet.dtype)
member.summary: Return evenly spaced values within a given interval.

Spacing between values. For any output out, this is the distance between two adjacent values, out[i+1] - out[i]. The default step size is 1. If step is specified, start must also be given.
The type of the output array. If dtype is not given, infer the data type from the other input arguments.
member.returns: Array of evenly spaced values
member.notes: For floating point arguments, the length of the result is ceil((stop - start)/step). Because of floating point overflow, this rule may result in the last element of out being greater than stop.
When using a non-integer step, such as 0.1, the results will often not be consistent. It is better to use linspace for these cases.

Spacing between values. For any output out, this is the distance between two adjacent values, out[i+1] - out[i]. The default step size is 1. If step is specified, start must also be given.
The type of the output array. If dtype is not given, infer the data type from the other input arguments.
member.returns: Array of evenly spaced values
member.notes: For floating point arguments, the length of the result is ceil((stop - start)/step). Because of floating point overflow, this rule may result in the last element of out being greater than stop.
When using a non-integer step, such as 0.1, the results will often not be consistent. It is better to use linspace for these cases.

member.name: M:NumpyDotNet.np.ObjectDepthAndDimension(System.Object,System.Int64[],System.Int32,System.Int32,System.Boolean)
member.summary:
Walks a set of nested lists (or tuples) to get the dimensions. The dimensionality must be consistent for each nesting level. Thus, if one level is a mix of lsits and scalars, it is truncated and all are assumed to be scalar objects.
That is, [[1, 2], 3, 4] is a 1-d array of 3 elements. It just happens that element 0 is an object that is a list of [1, 2].
member.param: Input object to talk
Array of dimensions of size 'max' filled in up to the return value
Current iteration depth, always start with 0
Size of dims array at the start, then becomes depth so far when !firstElem
True if processing the first element of the list (populates dims), false for subsequent (checks dims)
member.returns: Number of dimensions (depth of nesting)

member.name: M:NumpyDotNet.np.FromIEnumerable(System.Collections.Generic.IEnumerable{System.Object},NumpyDotNet.dtype,System.Boolean,System.Int32,System.Int32)
member.summary:
Builds an array from a sequence of objects. The elements of the sequence can also be sequences in which case this function recursively walks the nested sequences and builds an n dimentional array.
IronPython tuples and lists work as sequences.
member.param: Input sequence
Desired array element type or null to determine automatically
True if array should be Fortran layout, false for C
member.returns: New array instance

member.name: T:NumpyDotNet.NpyCoreApi
member.summary:
NpyCoreApi class wraps the interactions with the libndarray core library. It also makes use of NpyAccessLib.dll for a few functions that must be implemented in native code.
TODO: This class is going to get very large. Not sure if it's better to try to break it up or just use partial classes and split it across multiple files.

member.name: T:NumpyDotNet.NpyCoreApi.UseExistingWrapper
member.summary: Stupid hack to allow us to pass an already-allocated wrapper instance through the interfaceData argument and tell the wrapper creation functions like ArrayNewWrapper to use an existing instance instead of creating a new one. This is necessary because CPython does construction as an allocator but .NET only triggers code after allocation.

member.name: T:MachineCognitus.math
member.summary: Implements several C Standard mathematical functions that are missing from the .NET framework.

remarks.para: Both double and single precision functions are implemented. All functions are static and their names follow the C Standard. The class is named after the C header file where the functions are declared.

member.author: Robert Baron

remarks.para: Special values are treated as follows.

If is infinite, it is returned, and an undefined value is returned in .

member.name: M:MachineCognitus.math.ilogb(System.Double)
member.summary: Gets the unbiased exponent of the specified floating-point .
member.param: A floating-point number.
member.returns: The unbiased exponent of the specified floating-point , or a special value if is not normal or subnormal.

remarks.para: The unbiased exponent is the integral part of the logarithm base 2 of . The unbiased exponent is such that:
= significand() * 2^ilogb().
The return unbiased exponent is valid for all normal and subnormal numbers. Special values are treated as follows.
If is not zero, infinite, or NaN, the value returned is exactly equivalent to ()logb().

The value of the exponent returned by is always 1 less than the exponent retuned by because of the different normalization requirements: for , the normalized significand is in the interval [1, 2), but for , the normalized significand is in the interval [0.5, 1).
See ilogb in the C standard documentation.

member.summary: Gets the floating-point number that is next after in the direction of .
member.param: A floating-point number.
A floating-point number.
member.returns: The floating-point number that is next after in the direction of .

remarks.para: IEC 60559 recommends that be returned whenever == . These functions return instead, which makes the behavior around zero consistent: nextafter(-0.0, +0.0) returns +0.0 and nextafter(+0.0, -0.0) returns –0.0.
See nextafter in the C standard documentation.
